comments:
1. "File | New | Project..."
2. "Plugin Development | Fragment Project", Next
3. type any name for the project, Next
4. Next
5. Select "Create a fragment project using code generation wizard", Next
6. Pick any plug-in, e.g. "org.eclipse.ant.core", Finish.
PROBLEMS:
- error dialog is displayed "Problem occurred: java.lang.NullPointerException" 
and prevents the wizard from finishing. 
If you press "Cancel" you will see that the project was actually created but 
with further problems:
- fragment.xml file is not created;
- hierarchy of folders and files is incorrect ('src' folder is nested 
under 'bin' folder, duplicate .project and build.properties files)

This blocks our team from extending this wizard for an important customer 
project. The problem is not reproducible on 2.1.1 but we have a requirement to 
support Eclipse 2.0.2.

This one was fixed over a year ago.  Please try more recent releases.

Please read the original submission description:

"
This blocks our team from extending this wizard for an important customer 
project. The problem is not reproducible on 2.1.1 but we have a requirement to 
support Eclipse 2.0.2.
"

Is there any kind of patch we can use or recommend customers?

<quote>This blocks our team from extending this wizard for an important 
customer project.
</quote>

The wizard in question is not API (all the public classes and methods have a 
clear statement that they are experimental and subject to change i.e. not 
supported yet). As such, we are not in obligation to fix problems resulted 
from extending experimental code, particularly one from two releases back. 
That does not mean that we will not fix bugs in our regular process, just that
fixes in experimental code does not fit the description of 'critical fixes'
required for changes in the maintenance streams.

The current development release is 3.0. Previous supported release is 2.1.2, 
and this problem is fixed in that release. As far as I know, there will be
no new fixes in 2.0.* stream.

If at all possible, we suggest moving to 2.1.2 (which is fully backward
compatible with 2.0.*).

As Dejan pointed out, we are not supporting the 2.0.x stream.

Here is a possible workaround for 2.0.x:
If my memory serves me, this particular problem occurs when you are creating a 
fragment for an "external" plug-in.  If the plug-in you are creating a 
fragment for is in your workspace (e.g. imported via the plug-in import 
wizard), you would not run into the NPE.
